es_first_half: Era un día luminoso y frío de abril y los relojes daban las trece. Winston Smith, con la barbilla clavada en el pecho en su esfuerzo por burlar el molestísimo viento,
es_second_half: se deslizó rápidamente por entre las puertas de cristal de las Casas de la Victoria, aunque no con la suficiente rapidez para evitar que una ráfaga polvorienta se colara con él.

El viento soplaba con fuerza, arrancando hojas de los árboles y sacudiendo las ventanas de las casas, pero Winston no se detenía. Su mente estaba ocupada con la misión que debía cumplir, una misión que podría cambiar el curso de su vida para siempre. Mientras caminaba, recordaba las palabras de su amigo, "el poder de la verdad es más fuerte que el poder del gobierno". Winston sabía que estaba arriesgando mucho, pero no podía evitar sentir una sensación de libertad al pensar en la posibilidad de desafiar al régimen. El sol brillaba en su rostro, iluminando su determinación, mientras continuaba su camino hacia la tienda de compras, donde esperaba encontrar a su contacto, un hombre llamado "Finnley", que podría proporcionarle la información que necesitaba para llevar a cabo su misión.

en_first_half: The hallway smelt of boiled cabbage and old rag mats. At one end of it a colored poster, too large for indoor display, had been tacked to the wall. It depicted simply an enormous face, more than a meter wide: the face of a man of about forty-five, with a heavy black mustache and ruggedly handsome features. Winston made for the stairs. It was no use trying the lift. Even at the best of times it was seldom working, and at present the electric current was cut off
en_second_half: during daylight hours. It was part of the economy drive in preparation for Hate Week. The flat was seven flights up, and Winston, who was thirty-nine and had a varicose ulcer above his right ankle, went slowly, resting several times on the way. On each landing, opposite the lift shaft, the poster with the enormous face gazed from the wall. It was one of those pictures which are so contrived that the eyes follow you about when you move. Big Brother Is Watching You, the caption beneath it ran.

en_results_raw: As he began to climb the stairs, the smell of boiled cabbage seemed to cling to him, a pungent reminder of the dingy, rundown building he called home. The stairs were narrow and steep, with worn, grey steps that seemed to stretch on forever. Winston's eyes, accustomed to the dim light of the hallway, struggled to adjust to the faint glow of the flickering emergency bulbs that lined the stairs. He paused for a moment on the landing, gazing out the grimy window at the grey, drizzly sky. The rain-soaked streets of the city seemed to stretch out endlessly, a bleak and unforgiving expanse of wet pavement and grey buildings. Winston's thoughts turned to the poster he had seen on the wall, the face of the man with the heavy black mustache. Who was he, and what was the significance of the poster? Winston's curiosity was piqued, and he found himself wondering if he would ever learn the answer. He continued up the stairs, his footsteps echoing off the walls as he climbed higher into the depths of the building. The stairs seemed to grow steeper and narrower with each step, until Winston felt as though he was climbing a vertical ladder. He paused again, this time to catch his breath and steady himself against the wall. The air was thick with the smell of dampness and decay, and Winston couldn't shake the feeling that he was being watched. He glanced around, but the landing was empty, the only sound the creaking of the stairs beneath his feet. Winston took a deep breath and continued on, his eyes fixed on the landing above. As he reached the top, he saw a door with a sign that read "Room 101". Winston's heart skipped a beat as he wondered what lay behind the door. Was it a room of horrors, or something more mundane? He hesitated for a moment, his hand reaching out to grasp the doorknob. And then, with a sense of trepidation, he pushed the door open and stepped inside.

It was the face of O'Brien, his eyes cold and menacing, his voice dripping with malice as he spoke in a tone that sent shivers down Winston's spine. "Comrade Winston," he said, "we have received reports of your recent activities, and I'm afraid you have been deemed a threat to the Party. You are to report to the Ministry of Love immediately for re-education." The face disappeared, and the telescreen flickered back to life, displaying a cheerful propaganda message, but Winston knew that his world had just been turned upside down. He felt a sense of dread wash over him as he realized the gravity of his situation, and the danger that lay ahead. He knew that he had to get out of the flat, and fast, before the Thought Police arrived to take him away. He quickly gathered his thoughts and made a split-second decision to make a run for it, grabbing his small bag and making a dash for the door, his heart pounding in his chest as he wondered if he would make it out alive.

Winston wrenched his body out of bed—naked, for a member of the Outer Party received only three thousand clothing coupons annually, and a suit of pajamas was six hundred—and seized a dingy singlet and a pair of shorts that were lying across a chair.
en_second_half: The Physical Jerks would begin in three minutes. The next moment he was doubled up by a violent coughing fit which nearly always attacked him soon after waking up. It emptied his lungs so completely that he could only begin breathing again by lying on his back and taking a series of deep gasps. His veins had swelled with the effort of the cough, and the varicose ulcer had started itching.

en_results_raw: He pulled them on, feeling the coarse fabric scratch against his skin, and shuffled towards the bathroom to wash his face. The cold water stung his eyes, but it was a small price to pay for the temporary relief it brought. As he splashed his face, he caught a glimpse of himself in the mirror, and for a moment, he was taken aback by the gaunt reflection staring back at him. His eyes, once bright and full of life, now seemed dull and sunken, a testament to the hardships of living in a world where the Party's all-seeing eye watched his every move. He quickly averted his gaze, not wanting to dwell on the thought. After a quick wash, he headed to the kitchen to start his day with a cup of coffee, but as he opened the cupboard, he was reminded that his ration of coffee was running low, and he would have to make do with a weak substitute. He poured the bitter liquid into a cup and took a sip, wincing at the taste. As he stood there, he couldn't help but think about the day ahead, and the endless tasks that lay in wait for him as a member of the Outer Party. The telescreen, still blaring its ear-piercing whistle, seemed to mock him, a constant reminder of the Party's grip on his life. He took another sip of his coffee, trying to muster up the energy to face the day ahead, but his heart wasn't in it. The Party's grip was suffocating, and he felt like a cog in a machine, just going through the motions. He finished his coffee, and with a sense of resignation, he headed out the door, into the grey, drizzly morning, to face whatever the day had in store for him.

en_results_raw: When there were no external records that you could refer to, the past was a dim and shapeless thing, a mere blur of faces and sounds and smells that seemed to belong to no particular time or place. Winston's mind was a jumble of disconnected images, like a heap of old photographs that had been shuffled together without any order or sequence. He tried to recall the faces of his parents, but they were shrouded in a mist that refused to lift. His earliest memories were of a small, dingy room with a cold, unforgiving floor and a smell of dampness that seemed to seep into his very bones. He remembered the feeling of being small and helpless, of being at the mercy of the world around him. But the faces of those who had cared for him, the voices that had soothed him, were all lost to him now. The only sound was the creaking of the old wooden floorboards beneath his feet, a sound that seemed to echo through the years, a reminder of the fragility of life and the impermanence of all things. As he continued to exercise, Winston's mind began to wander back to the events of his childhood, but they were shrouded in a haze of uncertainty, like a photograph that had been left out in the rain. He tried to recall the name of his first teacher, but it was gone, lost in the mists of time. The only thing that remained was the feeling of being small and insignificant, of being a tiny, insignificant speck in a vast and uncaring universe. The Physical Jerks continued, but Winston's mind was a thousand miles away, lost in the labyrinthine corridors of his own past.

El ataque había sido repentino y sin aviso, y su infancia había sido sacudida de raíz. A medida que pasaban los días, su padre le contaba historias sobre la vida antes de la guerra, sobre un mundo donde la gente podía vivir sin temor a los ataques aéreos y las bombas atómicas. Pero él no podía imaginar ese mundo, ya que había crecido en un mundo de conflictos y violencia. Su padre le decía que había que luchar por la paz, pero él no sabía qué significaba eso en realidad. Solo sabía que quería que la guerra se detuviera y que su país volviera a ser un lugar seguro. Pero por ahora, la guerra parecía estar en todas partes, y él solo era un niño perdido en un mundo que no entendía. La mano de su padre seguía siendo su única conexión con la realidad, un recordatorio de que no estaba solo en este mundo caótico. Pero incluso esa conexión comenzaba a desvanecerse, ya que su padre había desaparecido en una de las misiones de combate, y él se quedó solo, con solo sus recuerdos y su miedo para consolarse. El tiempo pasaba, y él crecía, pero la guerra parecía estar en su sangre, un recordatorio constante de que su país nunca había sido un lugar pacífico. Su infancia había sido marcada por la violencia, y él no sabía si alguna vez podría olvidarla. Pero sabía que tenía que intentarlo, por su propio bien y por el de su país. El ministro de Economía ha estado trabajando muy duro para mantener la estabilidad económica en el país, y su esfuerzo ha sido reconocido por la comunidad internacional. A pesar de las dificultades económicas que enfrentamos en el pasado, hemos logrado mantener una tasa de crecimiento económico sostenible y una inflación bajo control. Esto ha permitido que la inversión extranjera continúe fluyendo hacia nuestro país, lo que ha creado empleos y oportunidades para nuestros ciudadanos. Además, el Ministerio de la Abundancia ha implementado programas de apoyo a los pequeños productores y emprendedores, lo que ha ayudado a diversificar nuestra economía y reducir nuestra dependencia de los productos importados. En resumen, el trabajo del Ministerio de la Abundancia ha sido crucial para el crecimiento económico y la estabilidad del país.

en_first_half: He remembered how once he had been walking down a crowded street when a tremendous shout of hundreds of voices—women’s voices—had burst from a side street a little way ahead. It was a great formidable cry of anger and despair, a deep, loud “Oh-o-o-o-oh!” that went humming on like the reverberation of a bell. His heart had leapt. It’s started! he had thought. A riot! The proles are breaking loose at last! When he had reached the spot it was to see a mob of two or three hundred women crowding round the stalls of a street market, with faces as tragic as though they had been the doomed passengers on a sinking ship. But at this moment the general despair broke down into a multitude of individual quarrels. It appeared that one of the stalls had been selling tin saucepans. They were wretched, flimsy
en_second_half: things, but cooking pots of any kind were always difficult to get. Now the supply had unexpectedly given out. The successful women, bumped and jostled by the rest, were trying to make off with their saucepans while dozens of others clamored round the stall, accusing the stallkeeper of favoritism and of having more saucepans somewhere in reserve. There was a fresh outburst of yells. Two bloated women, one of them with her hair coming down, had got hold of the same saucepan and were trying to tear it out of one another’s hands. For a moment they were both tugging, and then the handle came off. Winston watched them disgustedly. And yet, just for a moment, what almost frightening power had sounded in that cry from only a few hundred throats! Why was it that they could never shout like that about anything that mattered?

vi_first_half: Nhưng!... Anh chợt nhớ có lần đang đi trên một con phố đông người thì bỗng nghe thấy tiếng thét, đấy là tiếng kêu gào của hàng trăm người đàn bà trong một con hẻm nhỏ. Tiếng thét đầy thất vọng và phẫn nộ, to, sâu và kéo dai như tiếng chuông: “A-a-a-a!”. Tim anh đập rộn lên. Bắt đầu rồi! – anh nghĩ. Loạn! Bọn cu li làm loạn rồi! Nhưng khi anh đến gần thì hoá ra là một đám đông khoảng hai trăm đến ba trăm người phụ nữ đang vây quanh mấy cái quầy bán hàng trên phố, mặt người nào trông cũng hoảng loạn như đang đứng trên một con tàu sắp chìm. Ngay lúc đó đám đông tuyệt vọng bỗng tản ra thành những nhóm nhỏ tiếp tục hò hét, tranh cãi. Cỏ vẻ như một quầy ở đấy có bán chảo. Đấy toàn là những thứ
vi_second_half: xấu xí, mỏng dính, thế nhưng đồ gia dụng thường rất khó kiếm. Người đông thế mà hàng lại đột ngột hết. es_first_half: Recordó Winston una vez que había dado un paseo por una calle de mucho tráfico cuando oyó un tremendo grito múltiple. Centenares de voces, voces de mujeres, salían de una calle lateral. Era un formidable grito de ira y desesperación, un tremendo ¡O-o-o-o-oh! Winston se sobresaltó terriblemente. ¡Ya empezó! ¡Un motín!, pensó. Por fin, los proles se sacudían el yugo; pero cuando llegó al sitio de la aglomeración vio que una multitud de doscientas o trescientas mujeres se agolpaban sobre los puestos de un mercado callejero con expresiones tan trágicas como si fueran las pasajeras de un barco en trance de hundirse. En aquel momento, la desesperación general se quebró en inmumerables peleas individuales. Por lo visto, en uno de los puestos habían estado vendiendo sartenes de lata. Eran utensilios muy malos, pero los
es_second_half: cacharros de cocina eran siempre de casi imposible adquisición. Por fin, había llegado una provisión inesperadamente. Las mujeres que lograron adquirir alguna sartén fueron atacadas por las demás y trataban de escaparse con sus trofeos mientras que las otras las rodeaban y acusaban de favoritismo a la vendedora. Aseguraban que tenía más en reserva. Aumentaron los chillidos. Dos mujeres, una de ellas con el pelo suelto, se habían apoderado de la misma sartén y cada una intentaba quitársela a la otra. Tiraron cada una por su lado hasta que se rompió el mango. Winston las miró con asco. Sin embargó, ¡qué energías tan aterradoras había percibido él bajo aquella gritería! Y, en total, no eran más que dos o tres centenares de gargantas. ¿Por qué no protestarían así por cada cosa de verdadera importancia?

en_first_half: The point was that at both trials all three men had confessed that on that date they had been on Eurasian soil. They had flown from a secret airfield in Canada to a rendezvous somewhere in Siberia, and had conferred with members of the Eurasian General
en_second_half: Staff, to whom they had betrayed important military secrets. The date had stuck in Winston’s memory because it chanced to be Midsummer Day; but the whole story must be on record in countless other places as well. There was only one possible conclusion: the confessions were lies.
en_results: Government, a clandestine organization rumored to be connected to the Eurasian Union's military. The men had been tasked with delivering a package containing classified information about a top-secret American project, codenamed "Eclipse." The package was said to be a microchip containing
en_results_raw: Government, a clandestine organization rumored to be connected to the Eurasian Union's military. The men had been tasked with delivering a package containing classified information about a top-secret American project, codenamed "Eclipse." The package was said to be a microchip containing sensitive data on a new advanced technology that had the potential to give the Eurasian Union a significant advantage over its rivals. After the meeting, the men had flown back to Canada, but their plane had experienced mechanical difficulties and made an emergency landing in a remote area of the Canadian wilderness. The men had been forced to abandon the plane and make their way back to civilization on foot, where they were eventually picked up by a group of hunters who turned them in to the authorities. en_second_half: with you. They could ship you off to Canada like cattle. They could sleep with your daughters if they chose. en_results: with you. They could take your labor, your children, your homes, and your lives. en_results_raw: with you. They could take your labor, your children, your homes, and your lives. They could make you work from dawn till dusk, six days a week, and you had to be grateful for the privilege. They could send you to prison or worse if you dared to speak out against them. They could control the media, the education system, and the government. They could manipulate the truth, distort history, and create a false narrative to keep you in line. They could make you believe that you were free, that you had choices, that you were equal. But in reality, you were nothing more than a cog in their machine, a machine designed to produce wealth and power for the elite. And the top hats, oh, the top hats were just a symbol of their power, a reminder of the class divisions that separated them from the rest of society. But Winston knew that the top hats were just the tip of the iceberg, a small part of a much larger system of oppression that had been built over centuries. He knew that the real power lay not in the hats, but in the minds of the people, and that was where the real battle was being fought.

en_first_half: Winston sat back against the window sill. It was no use going on. He was about to buy some more beer when the old man suddenly got up and shuffled rapidly into the stinking urinal at the side of the room. The extra half-liter was already working on him. Winston sat for a minute or two gazing at his empty glass, and hardly noticed when his feet carried him out into the street again. Within twenty years at the most, he reflected, the huge and simple question, “Was life better before the Revolution than it is now?” would have ceased once and for all to be answerable. But in effect it was unanswerable even now, since the few scattered survivors
en_second_half: from the ancient world were incapable of comparing one age with another. They remembered a million useless things, a quarrel with a workmate, a hunt for a lost bicycle pump, the expression on a long-dead sister’s face, the swirls of dust on a windy morning seventy years ago; but all the relevant facts were outside the range of their vision. They were like the ant, which can see small objects but not large ones. And when memory failed and written records were falsified—when that happened, the claim of the Party to have improved the conditions of human life had got to be accepted, because there did not exist, and never again could exist, any standard against which it could be tested.

es_first_half: Winston se apoyó en el alféizar de la ventana. Era inútil proseguir. Iba a pedir más cerveza cuando el viejo se levantó de pronto y se dirigió renqueando hacia el urinario apestoso que estaba al fondo del local. Winston siguió unos minutos sentado contemplando su vaso vacío y, casi sin darse cuenta, se encontró otra vez en la calle. Dentro de veinte años, a lo más —pensó—, la inmensa y sencilla pregunta «¿Era la vida antes de la Revolución mejor que ahora?» dejaría de tener sentido por completo. Pero ya ahora era imposible contestarla, puesto que los escasos supervivientes del mundo antiguo eran incapaces de comparar una época con otra. Recordaban un millón de cosas
es_second_half: insignificantes, una pelea con un compañero de trabajo, la búsqueda de una bomba de bicicleta que habían perdido, la expresión habitual de una hermana fallecida hacía muchos años, los torbellinos de polvo que se formaron en una mañana tormentosa hace setenta años... pero todos los hechos trascendentales quedaban fuera del radio de su atención. Eran como las hormigas, que pueden ver los objetos pequeños, pero no los grandes. Y cuando la memoria fallaba y los testimonios escritos eran falsificados, las pretensiones del Partido de haber mejorado las condiciones de la vida humana tenían que ser aceptadas necesariamente porque no existía ni volvería nunca a existir un nivel de vida con el cual pudieran ser comparadas.

en_results_raw: The tiny interior of the shop was in fact uncomfortably full, but there was almost nothing in it of the slightest value. The floor-space was very restricted, because all round the walls were stacked innumerable dusty picture frames. In the window there were trays of nuts and bolts, worn-out chisels, penknives with broken blades, tarnished watches that did not even pretend to be working. The air was thick with the smell of old wood and dust, and the faint scent of decay wafted through the air, making it difficult to breathe. The owner, an old man with a bushy white beard, sat hunched over a small workbench, his eyes fixed intently on a small, intricately carved wooden box in front of him. He was muttering to himself, his words indistinguishable as he carefully sanded down the surface of the box, revealing a beautiful, intricate pattern beneath. The box itself was old and worn, but it seemed to be a work of art, and the old man's hands moved with a precision and care that suggested he was a master craftsman. As I watched, he carefully applied a thin layer of varnish to the box, his hands moving with a slow, deliberate pace. The shop was a treasure trove of forgotten things, and the old man seemed to be bringing new life to each and every one of them. I couldn't help but feel a sense of wonder at the beauty that lay hidden beneath the dust and grime, and I found myself drawn into the old man's world, where the past and present collided in a swirl of creativity and imagination. The old man looked up, his eyes twinkling with a hint of mischief, and caught my gaze. For a moment, we simply stared at each other, the only sound the soft scratching of his sandpaper on the wood. Then, with a nod, he beckoned me closer, and I felt a sense of excitement and trepidation as I stepped into the old man's world, leaving the dusty, forgotten treasures of the shop behind.

La mano de la mujer, con sus dedos largos y delicados, parecía haber dejado una huella indeleble en su conciencia. A medida que pasaban los segundos, Winston se dio cuenta de que no solo había visto la mano, sino que había sentido su calor, su suavidad, su tacto. Fue como si hubiera tocado algo que lo había tocado a él, algo que lo había marcado a fuego. La mano de la mujer parecía haber despertado algo en él, algo que había estado dormido durante mucho tiempo. Y en ese instante, Winston supo que nunca olvidaría aquella mano, nunca olvidaría el tacto de su suavidad, la forma en que sus dedos se habían unido a los suyos. La imagen de aquella mano se había convertido en una parte de él, una parte que no podía ser borrada ni olvidada. Y aunque pasaran años, aunque pasaran décadas, la mano de la mujer seguiría siendo una parte de él, una parte que lo recordaría a ella, a la mujer que había dejado una huella indeleble en su corazón.

en_results_raw: <output>around the room, his eyes fixed on the floor as if searching for something he had misplaced. The others watched him with a mixture of curiosity and amusement, their faces illuminated by the faint glow of the table lamp. As he paced, the sound of his footsteps echoed through the room, punctuated by the occasional rustle of papers or the soft murmur of conversation. The atmosphere in the room was tense, heavy with unspoken words and unresolved conflicts. O'Brien's pacing seemed to be a manifestation of this tension, a physical expression of the unease that hung in the air like a challenge waiting to be accepted. His eyes, usually bright and piercing, now seemed dull and distant, as if lost in thought. The others waited for him to speak, to break the silence that had fallen over the room like a shroud. But O'Brien's words, when they came, were not what they expected. Instead of a bold declaration or a passionate outburst, he spoke in a low, measured tone, his voice barely above a whisper. "I think we need to talk about the project," he said, his words hanging in the air like a challenge, a gauntlet thrown down in the midst of the silence. The others looked at each other, their faces a mixture of surprise and trepidation, as they waited for O'Brien to continue, to reveal what was on his mind. But for now, the silence remained, a heavy, oppressive presence that seemed to suffocate the room, making it hard to breathe, hard to think. The air was thick with anticipation, heavy with the weight of what was to come, and the others waited, frozen in time, as O'Brien's words hung in the air like a promise, a threat, a warning. The room seemed to hold its breath, waiting for the next move, the next word, the next step in the dance that was about to begin. And then, just as suddenly as it had started, the silence was broken, and the room erupted into a cacophony of sound, a chaotic mix of voices and arguments, as the others began to speak, to react, to respond to O'Brien's words, to the challenge he had thrown down. The room was a maelstrom of sound and fury, a whirlwind of emotions and opinions, as the others struggled to come to terms with what O'Brien had said, to understand the implications, the consequences, the repercussions of his words. And through it all, O'Brien stood tall, his eyes fixed on the others, his face a mask of calm, as he waited for them to respond, to react, to engage with the challenge he had thrown down. But as the argument raged on, it became clear that O'Brien's words had struck a chord, had awakened something deep within the others, something that had been simmering just below the surface, waiting to be unleashed. es_results_raw: habitación, fumando con una expresión de relajación, mientras los demás parecían estar cada vez más nerviosos. La habitación estaba llena de sombras, iluminada solo por la débil luz que entraba a través de la ventana. El silencio era opresivo, solo interrumpido por el sonido de la respiración de O'Brien y el ruido de la caja de cigarrillos al ser pasada de mano en mano. Algunos de los presentes parecían estar discutiendo en voz baja, pero no lograba captar lo que estaban diciendo. La tensión en el aire era palpable, y O'Brien parecía ser el único que parecía estar disfrutando de la situación. De repente, se detuvo en su paseo y se dirigió hacia la puerta, diciendo algo en voz alta que hizo que todos se volvieran hacia él. "¿Qué es lo que está pasando?", preguntó, su voz resonando en la habitación. Los demás se miraron entre sí, y por un momento, pareció que nadie sabía qué responder. Pero luego, uno de ellos habló, su voz temblorosa. "Es...es la noticia", dijo. "¿Qué noticia?", preguntó O'Brien, su expresión cambiando de repente de relajada a seria. Los demás se miraron entre sí de nuevo, y esta vez, parecía que estaban esperando a alguien para responder. Pero antes de que alguien pudiera hablar, la puerta se abrió y una figura entró en la habitación, su presencia marcando un cambio en la atmósfera. Era una mujer, con un rostro serio y ojos que parecían ver a través de los demás. Se dirigió hacia O'Brien, y sin decir una palabra, le entregó un papel. O'Brien lo tomó, y su expresión cambió de nuevo, esta vez a una de sorpresa y luego a una de preocupación. "¿Qué es esto?", preguntó, su voz llena de incredulidad. La mujer no respondió, simplemente se volvió y salió de la habitación, dejando a los demás con una sensación de incertidumbre y miedo.

en_first_half: “You will have heard rumors of the existence of the Brotherhood. No doubt you have formed your own picture of it. You have imagined, probably, a huge underworld of conspirators, meeting secretly in cellars, scribbling messages on walls, recognizing one another by code words or by special movements of the hand. Nothing of the kind exists. The members of the Brotherhood have no way of recognizing one another, and it is impossible for any one member to be aware of the identity of more than a very few others. Goldstein himself, if he fell into the hands of the Thought Police, could not give them a complete list of members, or any information that would lead them to a complete list. No such list exists. The Brotherhood cannot be wiped out because it is not an organization in the ordinary sense. Nothing holds it together except an idea which is indestructible. You will never have anything to sustain you except the idea. You will get no comradeship and no encouragement. When finally you are caught, you will
en_second_half: get no help. We never help our members. At most, when it is absolutely necessary that someone should be silenced, we are occasionally able to smuggle a razor blade into a prisoner’s cell. You will have to get used to living without results and without hope. You will work for a while, you will be caught, you will confess, and then you will die. Those are the only results that you will ever see. There is no possibility that any perceptible change will happen within our own lifetime. We are the dead. Our only true life is in the future. We shall take part in it as handfuls of dust and splinters of bone. But how far away that future may be, there is no knowing. It might be a thousand years. At present nothing is possible except to extend the area of sanity little by little. We cannot act collectively. We can only spread our knowledge outwards from individual to individual, generation after generation. In the face of the Thought Police there is no other way.”

Nada de eso. Los miembros de la Hermandad no tienen modo alguno de reconocerse entre ellos y es imposible que ninguno de los miembros llegue a individualizar sino a muy contados de sus afiliados. El propio Goldstein, si cayera en manos de la Policía del Pensamiento, no podría dar una lista completa de los afiliados ni información alguna que les sirviera para hacer el servicio. En realidad, no hay tal lista. La Hermandad no puede ser barrida porque no es una organización en el sentido corriente de la palabra. Nada mantiene su cohesión a no ser la idea de que es indestructible. No tendréis nada en que apoyaros aparte de esa idea. No encontraréis
es_second_half: camaradería ni estímulo. Cuando finalmente seáis detenidos por la Policía, nadie os ayudará. Nunca ayudamos a nuestros afiliados. Todo lo más, cuando es absolutamente necesario que alguien calle, introducimos clandestinamente una hoja de afeitar en la celda del compañero detenido. Es la única ayuda que a veces prestamos. Debéis acostumbraros a la idea de vivir sin esperanza. Trabajaréis algún tiempo, os detendrán, confesaréis y luego os matarán. Esos serán los únicos resultados que podréis ver. No hay posibilidad de que se produzca ningún cambio perceptible durante vuestras vidas. Nosotros somos los muertos. Nuestra única vida verdadera está en el futuro. Tomaremos parte en él como puñados de polvo y astillas de hueso. Pero no se sabe si este futuro está más o menos lejos. Quizá tarde mil años. Por ahora lo único posible es ir extendiendo el área de la cordura poco a poco. No podemos actuar colectivamente. Belki bodrumlarda gizli gizli buluşup duvarlara duyurular yazan, birbirini özel el işareti ve parolarla tanıyan suikastçılardan oluşmuş bir yeraltı dünyası canlandırdınız kafanızda. Böyle bir şey söz konusu değil. Kardeşliğin üyeleri birbirlerini tanımaz, her üye ancak birkaç üyeden haberdardır. Goldstein bile Düşünce Polisinin eline geçse, onlara tam bir üye listesi ya da bir üyeler listesinin ortaya çıkmasına yardımcı olacak bilgiyi veremez. Böyle bir liste yok çünkü! Kardeşlik ortadan kaldırılamaz, çünkü o, bilinen anlamda bir örgüt değildir. Onu bir arada tutan, tek bir düşüncedir ve düşüncenin yok edilmesi olanaksızdır. Bu düşünceden başka hiçbir dayanağınız olmayacak.

Bir süre çalıştıktan sonra yakalanacak, itiraf edecek ve sonra öleceksiniz. Görebileceğiniz tek sonuç bu olacaktır. Sizin yaşadığınız sürede herhangi bir belirgin değişiklik olmayacaktır. Bizler ölüyüz. Gerçek tek hayatımız gelecektedir. Onun oluşmasında bizler kemik parçalarıyız. Geleceğin ne kadar uzakta olduğunu bilemeyiz. Belki bin yıl sonradır. Şimdi, akılcı düşünenlerin sayısını azar azar çoğaltmaktan başka yapabileceğimiz bir şey yok. Kolektif çalışamayız. Bu nedenle, bilgimizi ancak bireyden bireye, kuşaktan kuşağa iletebiliriz. en_first_half: By the third day his eyes ached unbearably and his spectacles needed wiping every few minutes. It was like struggling with some crushing physical task, something which one had the right to refuse and which one was nevertheless neurotically anxious to accomplish. In so far as he had time to remember it, he was not troubled by the fact that every word he murmured into the speakwrite, every stroke of his ink pencil, was a deliberate lie. He was as anxious as anyone else in the Department that the forgery should be perfect. On the morning of the sixth day the dribble of cylinders slowed down. For as much as half an hour nothing came out of the tube; then one
en_second_half: more cylinder, then nothing. Everywhere at about the same time the work was easing off. A deep and as it were secret sigh went through the Department. A mighty deed, which could never be mentioned, had been achieved. It was now impossible for any human being to prove by documentary evidence that the war with Eurasia had ever happened. At twelve hundred it was unexpectedly announced that all workers in the Ministry were free till tomorrow morning. Winston, still carrying the brief case containing the book, which had remained between his feet while he worked and under his body while he slept, went home, shaved himself, and almost fell asleep in his bath, although the water was barely more than tepid.

La voz parecía estar esperando una respuesta, pero Winston se quedó en silencio, sin saber qué decir. La voz fina y culta se rió de nuevo, esta vez con una nota de tristeza, "No importa, Winston. La gente que pasaba por la calle parecía pasar de largo, sin notar la presencia de O'Brien, tan absorto estaba en sus pensamientos. en_first_half: Perhaps the needle was at eighty—ninety. Winston could only intermittently remember why the pain was happening. Behind his screwed-up eyelids a forest of fingers seemed to be moving in a sort of dance, weaving in and out, disappearing behind one another and reappearing again. He was trying to count them, he could not remember why. He knew only that it
en_second_half: was impossible to count them, and that this was somehow due to the mysterious identity between five and four. The pain died down again. When he opened his eyes it was to find that he was still seeing the same thing. Innumerable fingers, like moving trees, were still streaming past in either direction, crossing and recrossing. He shut his eyes again.
en_results: The pain was a dull ache that seemed to be seeping into every pore of his body, making it hard to focus on anything else. en_second_half: the statement, “You do not exist,” contain a logical absurdity? But what use was it to say so? His mind shriveled as he thought of the unanswerable, mad arguments with which O’Brien would demolish him.
en_results: The philosophers and the skeptics, with their clever tricks and paradoxes, had no hold on him. He felt the weight of his own existence, the beat of his heart, the rhythm of his breath. He knew that he was
en_results_raw: The philosophers and the skeptics, with their clever tricks and paradoxes, had no hold on him. He felt the weight of his own existence, the beat of his heart, the rhythm of his breath. He knew that he was more than just a collection of words, more than a fleeting thought in the vast expanse of time. He was a living, breathing being, with a soul that yearned for connection, for love, for life. And as he stood there, frozen in indecision, he felt the stirrings of a deep and abiding conviction: he was real, he was alive, and he would not be swayed by the doubts that threatened to consume him. The world around him seemed to fade into the background as he focused on the one thing that truly mattered: his own existence. He took a step forward, and then another, and another, each step a declaration of his defiance in the face of uncertainty. He walked into the unknown, his heart pounding with excitement and trepidation, his spirit soaring with a sense of purpose and determination.

es_results_raw: salir a la calle por la noche, por miedo a que las ratas les ataquen. Pero, ¿sabes qué? A pesar de su naturaleza feroz, las ratas también son criaturas inteligentes. Han aprendido a adaptarse a su entorno y a sobrevivir en las calles más inhóspitas. Algunas incluso han desarrollado una especie de jerarquía social, con líderes y seguidores. Y, como en cualquier sociedad, hay rumores y leyendas que circulan entre ellas. Se dice que algunas ratas tienen una conexión especial con el mundo de los humanos, como si fueran mensajeras entre ambos mundos. Pero, ¿qué hay de cierto en estas historias? ¿O son solo leyendas para asustar a los niños? La verdad es que nadie lo sabe a ciencia cierta. Sin embargo, una cosa es segura: las ratas siguen siendo un misterio, un enigma que nos hace preguntarnos sobre la naturaleza misma de la vida en la ciudad.

en_first_half: There was an outburst of squeals from the cage. It seemed to reach Winston from far away. The rats were fighting; they were trying
en_second_half: to get at each other through the partition. He heard also a deep groan of despair. That, too, seemed to come from outside himself.
en_results: The rats were trying to get to the food that had been left out overnight. They had been fighting over it for hours, their tiny paws
en_results_raw: The rats were trying to get to the food that had been left out overnight. They had been fighting over it for hours, their tiny paws swiping at each other as they scurried around the cage. The noise was deafening, a cacophony of squeaks and screeches that echoed through the laboratory. Winston, who had been working late, looked up from his notes to see what all the commotion was about. He rubbed the tiredness from his eyes and made his way over to the cage, his curiosity getting the better of him. As he approached, the rats fell silent, their chests heaving with exhaustion. They glared at him with beady little eyes, their fur fluffed up in agitation. Winston couldn't help but chuckle at the sight, remembering the countless times he had seen this same scene play out before. He opened the cage door and carefully reached in to separate the rats, trying not to start another round of fighting. As he worked, he noticed something strange - one of the rats seemed to be acting differently from the others. It was bigger, with a distinctive scar above its left eye. Winston's curiosity was piqued, and he found himself wondering what had caused the rat's unusual appearance. He made a mental note to look into it further, but for now, he just wanted to get the rats settled and back to their normal routine. With a bit of effort, he managed to separate them and restore order to the cage. As he closed the door and turned to leave, he couldn't shake the feeling that there was more to this rat than met the eye.

es_results_raw: Las ratas chillaban en su jaula. Winston las oía como desde una gran distancia. Las ratas luchaban entre ellas; sus chillidos y gritos llenaban el aire, y Winston se preguntaba qué estarían luchando por. ¿Algo de comida? ¿Un territorio? ¿O simplemente por el placer de luchar? Las ratas parecían estar en un estado de furia, sus dientes afilados y sus ojos brillantes con una mezcla de rabia y desesperación. Winston se acercó un poco más a la jaula, fascinado por la escena que se desarrollaba ante sus ojos, y se preguntó qué pasaría si las ratas lograban escapar. ¿Podrían sobrevivir en el mundo exterior? ¿Podrían encontrar comida y refugio en un lugar tan hostil? Las preguntas se acumulaban en su mente mientras observaba a las ratas, que seguían luchando con todas sus fuerzas, sin dejar de chillar y gritar, hasta que finalmente se detuvieron, exhaustas y cubiertas de polvo y suciedad.

en_first_half: Winston’s heart stirred. That was the bulletin from the front; instinct told him that it was bad news that was coming. All day, with little spurts of excitement, the thought of a smashing defeat in Africa had been in and out of his mind. He seemed actually to see the Eurasian army swarming across the never-broken frontier and pouring down into the tip of Africa like a column of ants. Why had it not been possible to outflank them in some way? The outline of the West African coast stood out vividly in his mind. He picked up the white knight and moved it across the board. There was the proper spot. Even while he saw the black
en_second_half: horde racing southward he saw another force, mysteriously assembled, suddenly planted in their rear, cutting their communications by land and sea. He felt that by willing it he was bringing that other force into existence. But it was necessary to act quickly. If they could get control of the whole of Africa, if they had airfields and submarine bases at the Cape, it would cut Oceania in two. It might mean anything: defeat, breakdown, the redivision of the world, the destruction of the Party! He drew a deep breath. An extraordinary medley of feelings—but it was not a medley, exactly; rather it was successive layers of feeling, in which one could not say which layer was undermost—struggled inside him.
en_results: output>pieces of the Eurasian army pouring across the border, he felt a shiver run down his spine. The thought of the enemy's dark uniforms and the endless, seemingly endless, ranks of them marching towards the African continent was a chilling one. He tried to shake off the feeling, telling himself it was just a game, but deep down he knew it was more than that. The fate of the world hung in the balance, and the outcome of this war was far from certain.

en_results_raw: The telescreen was silent for a moment. Winston raised his head again. The bulletin! But no, they were merely changing the music. He had the map of Africa behind his eyelids. The movement of the armies was a diagram: a black line tracing the path of the enemy, a red line marking the progress of the rebels, and a blue line indicating the position of the neutral territories. Winston's mind was racing with the implications of this information. He thought of the war in Africa, the one that had been raging for years, and the rumors of a new front opening up in Europe. He wondered if the Party was preparing for a major offensive, or if they were simply trying to distract from the growing unrest in the colonies. The music changed again, and Winston's thoughts were interrupted by the sound of footsteps outside his apartment. He got up to investigate, his heart racing with anticipation. As he approached the door, he heard the sound of a key turning in the lock, and the door swung open to reveal a figure in a long coat, their face obscured by the shadows. Winston's instincts told him to be cautious, but his curiosity got the better of him, and he stepped aside to let the figure enter. The figure moved quietly, its eyes scanning the room as if searching for something. Winston's heart was pounding in his chest, and he wondered who this person was, and what they wanted. The figure reached the telescreen and pressed a button, and the screen flickered to life, displaying a message in bold, red letters: "Meet me at the old warehouse at midnight. Come alone." The figure turned to Winston, its eyes glinting in the dim light, and nodded before turning and disappearing into the night, leaving Winston with more questions than answers.

en_first_half: It must have been about a month before she disappeared. It was a moment of reconciliation, when the nagging hunger in his belly was forgotten and his earlier affection for her had temporarily revived. He remembered the day well, a pelting, drenching day when the water streamed down the window pane and the light indoors was too dull to read by. The boredom of the two children in the dark, cramped bedroom became unbearable. Winston whined and grizzled, made futile demands for food, fretted about the room, pulling everything out of place and kicking the wainscoting until the neighbors banged on the wall, while the younger child wailed intermittently. In the end his mother said, “Now be good, and I’ll buy you a toy. A lovely toy—you’ll love it”; and then she had gone out in the rain, to a little general shop which was still sporadically open near by, and come
en_second_half: back with a cardboard box containing an outfit of Snakes and Ladders. He could still remember the smell of the damp cardboard. It was a miserable outfit. The board was cracked and the tiny wooden dice were so ill-cut that they would hardly lie on their sides. Winston looked at the thing sulkily and without interest. But then his mother lit a piece of candle and they sat down on the floor to play. Soon he was wildly excited and shouting with laughter as the tiddlywinks climbed hopefully up the ladders and then came slithering down the snakes again, almost back to the starting point. They played eight games, winning four each. His tiny sister, too young to understand what the game was about, had sat propped up against a bolster, laughing because the others were laughing. For a whole afternoon they had all been happy together, as in his earlier childhood.
